Dear Diane Marquess:
Attached is the Renewal Inspection Report for the above referenced agency completed
on 10/4/2023. Due to the violations of applicable licensing rules, a written corrective action
plan is required. The corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this letter and
must include the following:
• For any repeat violations, why the prior corrective action plan did not result
in compliance.
• How compliance with each citation will be achieved.
• Who is directly responsible for implementing the action steps in the
corrective action plan.
• Specific time frames for each citation as to when the correction will be
completed or implemented.
• How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
• The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you fail to submit an acceptable corrective action plan, disciplinary action may result.
Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact the area manager at (616) 204-6992.

Sincerely,

III. DESCRIPTION OF FINDINGS
The agency is in compliance with all applicable rules and statutes except for the
following:
CCI Rule 400.4113 Employee records.
(1)An institution shall maintain employee records for
each employee and shall include documentation of all
of the following information prior to employment or at
the time specified in this rule:

(e) Three dated references which are obtained prior to
employment from persons unrelated to the employee
and which are less than 12 months old.
One of six employee files reviewed (under one year of employment) did not have
the required three references documented in the file. This employee had worked
at the agency in another department and transferred and was hired at the facility.
There were no references found in the file.

VI. EVALUATION OF RENEWAL PERIOD
Maltreatment in Care
There were no substantiated incidents of maltreatment in care during this licensing
period.
Corrective Action Plan Compliance
The agency has submitted 1 acceptable corrective action plans (CAP) during this
licensing period, and compliance with each individual CAP is as follows: The single
CAP was in regard to last year's interim licensing inspection and involved one
employee not having the three required references documented in the file. These
same issues occurred during this inspection and will be noted as a repeat
violation.
Financial Overview
There are no financial concerns identified based on the review of the facility's
budget and the agency's financial audit.
PREA compliance (if applicable)
N/A
Chief Administrator Assessment
The Chief Administrator noted there was one special investigation during this
reporting period and no violations were found. It is also noted there were no
restraints during this period and no barriers or systemic factors impacting the

facility. A case manager was hired, and the facility is still in the process of hiring a
fulltime therapist to provide services. During each team meeting, motivational
interviewing and de-escalation training to conducted and the CA noted the results
have been no restraints this period. There were 13 discharges during this period
and all 13 were planned. The CA also notes that the youth referred to the program
during this period have needed further residential care and were unable to function
in a family setting at the time of discharge. The facility developed a plan to
increase staff training to recognize trauma responses from the youth and the
results have been a reduction in restraints. Staff are also expected to participate in
the facility's wellness activities. Lastly, the facility is hiring a human resources
partner to assist the operations director with hiring requirements.
Staff and Youth Interviews
All staff interviewed reported trainings on motivational interviewing and recognizing
trauma. They feel supported by administration and believe the training are very
helpful in their positions.
The youth interviewed reported feeling safe and cared for at the facility. The youth
believes staff treat her fairly and support her efforts to change.
Description of Agency Walk Through
Single story facility licensed for 6 youth with each having their own bedroom. The
bedrooms are furnished appropriately, and the facility is well maintained. All
plumbing is in working order and the facility was well stocked with food and fresh
items of food. The menu was posted as was the emergency phone numbers. The
medication and cleaning supplies were locked according to the rules. The bed
check log and emergency drills log were observed, and all were appropriate.

VII. RECOMMENDATION
Based on inspection findings the agency is not in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules. Upon receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, it is
recommended that the agency will be issued a renewal of their regular license.
